review_title: Great place but really low pay
pros: Great staff and benefit packages
cons: Way lower pay then neighboring hospitals

pros: I work for an offshoot of ECHN. My company is great; the flexibility is fantastic (I'm able to do last minute errands and they don't care as long as my hours are met and my job is done). I would recommend the job because of this alone. Medical insurance is great as long as you stay within the network. If you need a specialist, for example, a neurologist, you're outta luck because we don't have one. The closest neurologist in network is in the Waterbury area. They do cover hearing aids, surprisingly (most insurances don't), but there's only a $2000 total allowance per year. Good luck if your hearing aids cost more than that. Dental is so-so. Standard cleanings & X-rays are covered 100%, but if you need orthodontic work, the lifetime maximum is $1500, & all orthodontic office visits are only 50% covered by the insurance, with the rest falling to you. Vision is decent.
cons: ECHN is miserly when it comes to giving raises. The average raise is 2% and is done at the beginning of the year (when they decide to give one). There are no merit raises. It's nearly mid-February as of this writing, and there has been zero news from C-Suite on raises this year. They know we're hurting, especially because of inflation and COL increases; they just don't care. The salary band for all positions are embarrassingly low, unless you're in C-Suite. If you hit the ceiling in your position, you cannot make more money unless you make a move elsewhere in the company or by leaving the company. I have no children and have no partner, so I work a ton of overtime to just barely keep my head above water. I would love to stop since 2.5 years of constant overtime does wear on the body, but I can't because they pay too little for me to make it on base salary. The pay rate goes to 4 decimal points, for no other reason than "the system's set to it." When asked to bring it down to the standard 2, the response was "No, it'd mess with your pay rate." Annual reviews are straightforward (meets/doesn't meet expectations)...when it's done at all. They procrastinate on creating positions in departments that need them and would prefer to shove them to the side because it's not as important. We've been begging HR & higher ups to add a position to a department for the last 2.5 years. They've ignored us the entire time or done the "We need to discuss XYZ first then we'll talk." game. I've been waiting for a promotion and to be trained in a different department for 2 years. We're so shorthanded that bosses are stretched thin trying to cover people's leaves and vacations that I've gotten shunted to the side. Work/life balance was great pre-COVID. As of now, it's nonexistent. Again, because we're chronically shortstaffed we're constantly on high stress mode to keep on top of things before month end.

pros: Great management and good people to work with
cons: overtime is not an option

pros: You need money? They pay money. It's a union job (the union is useless) but you might be into that?
cons: Poor communication between departments. Staffing is a disaster. Education for nursing needs to go way beyond Foley catheter care. Safety is not a priority in this hospital. You will consistently be dangerously understaffed. Physicians push patients out in record time. Certain physicians don't answer pages. At all. "Everyone knows it" and no one does anything about it. No critical care physicians on site during evening or night hours. Some are hard to find during the day. No pharmacy staff at night. Inexperienced charge nurses.

job_title: Patient Care Provider in Manchester, CT
pros: Will hire you even if not qualified. In the midst of acquisition by larger organization. Just putting bodies in positions to make things look good. Was a strong community hospital at one time
cons: Senior leadership very poor, biding their time until merger done. Cutting costs, resources and positions without care for what it does to patient care. Nurse to patient ratio horrible. Needs to rebuild with new leadership that has handle on what other hospitals doing to be successful but also build strong foundation with staff and patient care. Everything they are doing is superficial and will crumble soon. Stay away unless desperate and be sure you have good malpractice insurance

pros: Flexible with work scheduling and overall nice people who want to do their best.
cons: Upper Management allows mid level management to run everything - too much micro management. Acceptable for management to base promotion and hiring decisions on personal feeling rather than ability to handle the job. This leads to a lot of turnover and discontent.

review_title: Many changes within the past couple years
pros: Most of the people I've come in contact with have been very friendly and willing to help you when you're new.
cons: So many changes going on with the company it's hard to keep up sometimes. One person says one thing and another says something else. Managers don't take suggestions seriously but more than happy to take credit for them when it benefits them.

review_title: Manchester Memorial Hospital is a HORRIBLE place to work
pros: You get every other holiday off.
cons: Health Insurance is awful. Previously, you were able to use your own physicians if you lives outside a certain radius. They are no changing it so you must use their health insurance regardless. You have to watch your paycheck closely because they constantly make mistakes and they pay you less then you're supposed to get. There are a few employees who have been their many years  but the majority leave as fast as they came. No opportunities for continuing education or advancement.
